cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.

The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.
SOLE AGENTS FOR Dudbridges Oil Engines from 1 to 35 B.H.P. as supplied to Sudan Government Seamless Steel Boat Co., Ltd., etc., etc. 31-10-906

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

If you seek Health, Rest, and Recreation, Do not Fail to Visit Helouan.
"The Tewfik is Helouan and Helouan is the Tewfik."
The Tewfik-Helouan,"should be known to all who purpose to visit Egypt. – Glasgow Herald.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"is surrounded by pure dessert air under the best possible conditions." – Lancet.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"enjoys an exceptional position." Egyptian Gazette.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"views from the windows absolutely charming – Egyptian Gazette.

div.head: CAIRO MENA HOUSE HOTEL
div.p: FIRST CLASS FAMILY HOTEL.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL
div.p: Open all the year. Unrivalled position in centre of Cairo, opposite Khedivial Opera House and Esbekieh Gardens. Magnificent Verandah, French Restaurant and Grill-room, Bars and Billiard Saloons open to non-residents. Supper after the theatre.
GEORGE NUNGOVICH HOTELS

div.head:
PAGNON'S HOTELS,
LUXOR.
div.p: LUXOR HOTEL.–This old established hotel, accommodating 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident Doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Light, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court.
KARNAK HOTEL.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.
Three-quarters of a Century's established Reputation
Neave's Food
for Infants, Invalids, and the Aged
"Admirably adapted to the wants of infants and young persons." Sir Chas. A Cameron, C.B., M.D.
Gold Medal awarded, Woman's Exhibition, London, 1900.
Neave' Food is specially prepared for keeping in hot climates and is packed in hermetically sealed Tins.
Manufacturers: Josiah R. Neave & Co., Fordingbridge, England.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1904.

div.head: THE PASSAGE OF THE FLEET.
div.p: We offer our sincere congratulations to the Government on the complete success of the measures which it adopted during the recent passage of the 2nd division of the Baltic Fleet through the Suez Canal. The stories spread by sensation-mongers and bruited abroad by members of the Russian secret service, who presumably wanted to show something for the pay squandered on them, had undoubtedly obtained general credence in Russian naval and political circles. The squadron was manned by crews most of whom knew as little of nautical life as Mr. W. 8. Gilbert's sea-lord, its officers, if of some professional standing, had expressed at Tangiers and elsewhere the most lively, and as the event proved, the most needless apprehension of a Japanese attack. All the materials were at hånd for a repetition of the Dogger incident which might have been fraught with the most calamitous consequences to the whole world. The effective patrolling of the banks and waters of the canal; the promptness with which our somewhat embarrassing guests have been escorted through the ditch' without accident or incident, and the entire absence of any hitch in the dispositions made by the Government, deserve unstinted praise. That there was & certain element of comedy in proceedings which recalled the spectacle of an agitated family being escorted over the safest of crossings, is obvious enough, but comedy might have been followed by the most appalling tragedy in the narrow waters of the canal but for the precautions of which we applaud the successful issue.

There can only be one opinion amongst those who were officially connected with the precautionary and other arrangements connected with the fleet's visit—thankfulness that no untoward incident took place. It was out of the question to suppose that the Japanese, who have behaved throughout the war with an exemplary correctness never excelled by any other nation, would be parties to any dastardly outrage in neutral waters. Trouble was only looked for from the Russian fleet itself. Every credit is due to the Canal Company's staff, the Coast Guards, and police officials, for the excellent manner in which the arrangements were made and carried out ; but whether they were made for the purpose of protecting the fleet from a possible treacherous Japanese attack, or for the purpose of comforting the excited minds of the officers of the fleet, and 80 saving them from once more making themselves notorious, it would perhaps not be well to ask.

The satirical article reprinted from the Pall Mall Gazette in our issue of 24th inst. was not altogether uncalled for. It is a fact that the authorities actually stopped the firing of the morning and evening Ramadan guns, lest the distant report should throw the fleet into another wild panic. Many of the other precautions taken were equally ludicrous, but they cannot be said to have been uncalled for. The wonder is that any admiral would allow his fleet to be nursed and tended in a way calculated to excite the contempt and ridicule of all nations.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
PORT ARTHUR.
GENERAL ATTACK PROGRESSING.
div.p: Tokio, November 21. The general attack on Port Arthur is progressing. The results are unknown. Geno rals Nakamura and Saito, who were leading specially trained bodies of swordsmen, charged into the Russian forts and engaged in a hand-to hand sanguinary encounter. The results of the charge are unknown.
(Router.)
MANCH URIA.
RIVERS FROZEN.
MUKDEN, November 27. Skirmishing continues. The rivers are completely frozen.
(Havas.)
ENGLAND AND THE WAR. AIDING THE RUSSIANS.
LONDON, November 26. The Japanese Legation positively denies the purchase of coals mentioned on the 23rd
inst.

Reuter's Agency understands that the shipments of British coal for Russia and the supply of munitions from British firms have excited many painful feelings among the Japanese. It is pointed out that subjects of Japan's ally are materially assisting Russia.
Baron Sayematsu, interviewed on the subject, is of opinion that Great Britain ought to do something in order to prevent a continuance of this situation.
(Reuter.)
CONFISCATION OF SS. "CHELTENHAM." CONFIRMED BY SUPREME
PRIZE COURT.
St. Petersburg, November 26. The Supreme Prize Court has confirmed the confiscation of the British steamer Cheltenham.
(Reuter.)
SEDITION IN RUSSIA RIOTS AT SEVASTOPOL.

SEVASTOPOL, November 26. Serious riots have occurred here amongst the sailors in barracks. The causes are somewhat obscure, but seditious proclamations were found in the men's effects. The sailors wrecked their own quarters, and also those of the officers belonging to other naval divisions, who refused to join them. The pickets fired upon the rioters, wounding many and evet: tually restoring order.

div.head: GENERAL NEWS.
div.p: ANGLO-RUSSIAN CONVENTION.
PUBLICATION OF TEXT.
London, November 27. The text of the Anglo-Russian Convention has been published. It contains no fresh features.

The Commission will inquire and report on all the circumstances of the incident, and particularly on the question of responsibility and the degree of blame attaching to the subjects of the contracting parties, or to the subjects of other countries, in the event of their responsibility being established. (Reuter.)
RUSSIAN RIFORM. TSAR AND ZEMSTVOS MOVEMENT.

ST. PETERSBURG, November 26. A deputation of prominent members of the Zemstvos, escorted by Prince Mirski, to-day submitted to the Tsar, at his own invitation, the resolutions mentioned on the 21st inst. The Tsar asked many questions, his attitude being syinpathetic.
(Reuter.) SECOND BALTIC SQUADRON.
BATTLESHIP DAMAGED.
ST. PETERSBURG, November 26. The battleship Oleg, which sailed with the last Baltic squadron, has returned to Libau, seriously damaged.
(Havas.) ADMISAL ALEXII FF. HONOURED BY THE TSAR.

ST. PETERSBURG, November 27. In connection with the removal of Admiral Alexeieff from the chief command in the Par East, an Imperial rescript expresses satisfaction with his services and confers on him the Order of Saint George of the Third Class. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, November 27. Admiral Alexeieff, on being relieved of his functions, has received a letter of thanks from the Tsar.
(Havas.)
U.S. A AND GERMANY. MUTUAL CONGRATULATIONS.
BERLIN, November 27. President Roosevelt and Emperor William have exchanged telegrams of congratulatior on the occasion of the unveiling of the statue of Frederick the Great at Washington.
(Havas.
MACEDONIA NAZIR PASHA AT SALONIKA.

SALONIKA, November 27. Nazir Pasha, Special Envoy of the Sultan has arrived here. He has received "cart blanche" to suppress the insurrectionary move ment, which latterly has assumed serious pro portions.
(Router
FRENCH EMBASSY AT VATICAN.
CREDITS SUPPRESSED.
Paris, November 26. The Chamber of Deputies has suppressed the credits for the embassy to the Vatican.
(Havas.)
THE KHEDIVE. After presiding at the Council of Ministers at Abdeen Palace on Saturday, the Khedive received Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy and the Orthodox Coptio Patriarch in a private audience.
This morning, his Highness went to Abdeen Palace and received the Marquis Salvago-Raggi and M. Gennadis, the Italian and Greek Diplomatic Agents.
The former presented to his Highness the Marquis Neli-Luchi de Sovogna, the new Italian Consul at Cairo, and the latter, M. Rika kis, attaché to the Greek Diplomatic Agency.
His Highness also received Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, Sheik Ahmed Pasha, and Mr. Fowler.
This afternoon his Highness will grant an audience to Michalla Pasha.
This evening his Highness will give an Iftar to the Princes of the Khedivial Family, the Ministers and Under-Secretaries of State, and to officials of the rank of Mirmiran.
"AU DE ROUGE.”
General Drapery Establishment. (Central Tramway Station ),
CAIRO. P. PLUNKETT,
PROPRIETOR. DIRECT IMPORTER OF BRITISH AND IRISH
TEXTILE MANUFACTURES. JUST ARRIVED-LATEST DESIGNS IN LADIES' 249.6 DRESS GOODS.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer,
& HOTEL COMPANY. RIVER TRANSPORT OF GOODS BETWEEN ALEXANDRIA & CAIRE
Three Sailings a-Week. Agenta at Alexandria: -
ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE CO.,LDB1.10.804
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
The 20th HUSSARS were inspected this morning by the General Officer Commanding.
PARIAT Dogs. Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Menshieh quarter of Alexandria this evening will be poisoned by the police.
Royal Berks' Move.--The advance party of the three companies R. Berks Regiment, which are proceeding to Cairo, will take over the barracks at Abbassich on Thursday next.

GAMBLING HELL RAID. -- The Alexandria police made a raid on a gambling hell in Tewfik Pasha-street last night and arrested the owner, the cards and money being seized and sent to the Attarin police station.

CATTLE PLAGUE - Mr. Hart, of the Serum Institute, Abbassieh, bas been appointed cattle plague inspector in the provinces of Fayoum and Beni Souef and the Fashn, Maghagha and Beni Mazar districts of Minieh, in place of Mr. Dray, who has resigned.

K. S.C. - Owners are reminded that nominations for the Paddock Handicap, to be run at the second Winter Meeting on the 25th and 27th January, 1905, close on 'Thursday, December 1. Owners who require paddock stalls for the coming season should apply at once as the number is limited.

EXECUTION.—The Bedouin, Aly Amir, who murdered his brother Ahmed Amir in the Assiout province on October 12, 1903, was executed on Saturday at the prison of the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo. The Commandant of Police and the Chief of the Native Parquet were present at the execution.

1 A MOST REMARKABLE EXAMPLE of the way in which the Anglo-Egyptian officials encourage British trade is seen in recent contracts given out by the Finance Ministry for articles in common use in the various Departments of the Government. More than half the ink is supplied from Hungary, although British firms tendered for the entire supply. Up to this year the whole supply was in British bands.

THE SUDD.--A paper by Mr. A. F. Brown, "Notes on the Sudd Formation of the Upper Nile," was read at the last meeting of the Linnean Society in abstract by Mr. C. H. Wright. The notes include the tract of country between Lake No and Shambe, a military post on the left bank, 266 miles from that lake. The author gave a list of the plants forming the mass of vegetation which, favored by the silt brought down by the White Nile, is helping to block the shallow channels.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
- Lord Curzon of Kodleston, Viceroy of India, is a passenger for Bombay by the P. &0. S.S. Persia, due at Port Said to-morrow.

Among those dining at Shepheard's Restaurant yesterday we noticed Col. Younghusband and some friends, Mr. F. C. Grew and a party of 8, Baron von Richthofen and a party of 5, Lady Duffey and party, Mr. Gordon Bennett, Marquis and Marquise d'Albufera, Baron and Baronne Gourgaud, Baronne de Reuter, and party, Mr. Loir, Mr. and Mrs. von Falcione, Mr. von Salisch, Michalla Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. de Kerautem, Mr. and Mrs. van der Wyck, Count Diepholz, Baron von Wersede, etc.
Lady Palmer is returning to Egypt shortly.
Mr. E. Tillard, as engineer to the Prisons Department, will receive a salary of L.E. 420 per annum.
Drs. Stanislao Rocchi and Constantin Papadimitriou have been authorized to practise in Egypt.
Mr. Rodih bas been transferred as engineer to the Ministry of Public Works.

The following is a list of the passengers who left for the Nile trip by the P. S. Nefertari on Friday :-Mr. R. D. Mann, Mr. Fox Strangeways, Mrs. Louisa and Miss Calthorp, Capt. and Mrs. Schneider, Oberst and Mrs. Isenbart, Mr. HansIsenbart, Miss Teschendorf, Dr. and Mrs. Vogler, M. and Mme. Nahas Bey, Miss Chance, Miss Dudgeon, Mr. E. M. and Mrs. Ashley, Mr. and Mrs. F. R. Ashley, Mr. Hunter Dunn, Miss Bruce, Miss Burnet, Mr. and Mrs. Lee, Rev. and Mrs. J. B. Bristow, Mr. J. Priolian, Mr. W. Vincent.
MISLEADING ADVERTISEMENTS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir,--My attention has been called to an absurdly inserted advertisement appearing in a paper called L'Egypte (The Egyptian Morning News) under the heading "Ellerman Lines, Ltd.," (City and City and Hall Lines), which is entirely incorrect and misleading, the steamers named therein being the Ellerman liners between London and Liverpool and Alexandria, for which I am agent. I shall be obliged by your calling attention to this in your next issue, as the only paper I advertise in at present is the Egyptian Gazette.
Yours truly,
N. E. TAMVACO. Alexandria, 26 November, 1904.

P.8.-L'Egypte has no authority from me or, I understand, from Messrs. Cory Brothers & Co., Ltd., the Port Said agents of the 'City' Line, to publish advertisements respecting our respective companies, N. E. T.
THE BUDGET FOR 1905.
THE ESTIMATES
The following are the budgetary estimates for 1905 :Revenne...
... L.E. 12,255,000 Expenditure: Ordinary ex
penditure L.E. 11,308,000 Special expenditure, 447,000
Surplus ... ... ... L.E. 500,000 The estimates of revenue do not include the LE. 216,000 taken from the General Reserve Fund for the relief of taxation.

The land transfer dues have been reduced to 2%, which has brought about a decrease in revenue of L.E.250,000. A diminution in receipts of L.E.16,000 is also provided for owing to the suppression of the boat dues. On the other hand, there figures in the Estimates a sum of L.E.135,000, being the product of the sales of Free State property.

The estimates of expenditure do not include the sum of L.E.265,000, representing the economies resulting from the conversion of the Privileged Debt, which have hitherto been paid into the Fonds des Economies de la Conversion.
The actual increase in the expenditure amounts to L.E. 604,000, the greater portion of which figures in the Budget of Public Works, Railways, and Public Instruction.
A sum of L.E. 447,000 has been set aside for the special expenditure of the year, which up to now had been taken from the Reserve Fund.

RAILWAY COMMISSION. We hear on good authority that the construction of the line from Salhieh to Kantara has been approved in principle, though work is not likely to be begun there till the Railway Commission has presented its report.

The members of the Commission left for Upper Egypt on Saturday. They inspected the Payoum line and stations and spent the night at Seilah station. Yesterday they inspected the line and stations between Wasta and Melawi.

COUNCIL OF MINISTERS. The Council of Ministers, which was held at Abdeen Palace on Saturday, gave its approval to the budgetary estimates for the coming year and to the Note of the Financial Adviser thereon. The fusion of the Helouan and Delta railways, the creation of a Sudan Irrigation Service, and the nomination of Messrs. Mitchell Innes and Rooca Serra to the Committee of Egyptian Antiquities also received the approbation of the Council.

IRRIGATION WORKS. By Khedivial decree the Moudirs of Gharbieh, Galioubieh, Dakahlieh, Keneh, and Assouan are commanded to convoke the provincial councils of their respective Moudiriehs to examine the local irrigation works proposed for 1905. In place of the chief engineers of the Moudiriehs the Inspectors of Irrigation may be present, with & voice in the deliberations of the councils.
The dates of these meetings are as follows: Galioubieb, Deo. 3; Gbarbieh, Deo.4, Dakahlieh, Dec. 5; Keneh, Dec. 24 ; Assouan, Dec. 27.

BRASSERIES DES PYRAMIDES. No less than 49,000 shares were applied for, but as the new issue only consisted of 5,000 shares, the share-holders of the company, who had the right of preference, were allotted 4,550 shares, while the outside public received one per cent.

THE HOUSING SCHEME. Mr. Geo. B. Alderson writes : - My scheme is not based on any plea of poverty nor want of work for artisans. The foundation of the whole idea is due to the utter want of accommodation Jin Alexandria for artisans. In consequence of this dearth of suitable houses, good, honest and industrious workmen have to live in "Tat holes." without water laid on, because the landlords fear that their houses would collapse if the water pipes leaked. The "rat holes" are never repaired because the landlords assert that they are not worth repairing. In many cases even these dwellings have only holes in the top of the walls for light. Their sanitary condition is deplorable. My demand for gas is confined to the corridors alone. The project of remitting the 2 % tenants tax on these sınall tenements, averaging £1 per month rent, is based on the enormous expense of collecting these taxes in such cases. The scheme is worked out on a commercial basis and would provide a sure and profitable savings bank for the artisan, I ask for land sufficient to build seven such blocks, which would accommodate, roughly, say 1,000 families, possibly more, as many would be subdivided. If it is too much to ask for the grant of the land, then I would ask for & perpetual lease at a peppercorn rent. If they ask us to purchase, then to raise the capital becomes a speculation, and I fear in the end we should be in the same plight again as we are now. If the above scheme is not feasible, how is this urgent want to be provided for
CARLTON HOTEL

Bulkeley, Ramleh. Fint Olses Botel. Newly builo. Era breezes. Dry Air. Near tram station, the promenado, and Mustapbs Pashs Barracks, Garden, Lawn Tennis. Good cuisine Modern to charges. Open all the year round. O. AQUILINA, proprietor. (Late of Thos. Cook & Sop): also General Manager, Tewók Palace Hotel Holonan.
CANEA OUTRAGES.
TERRIBLE SCENES.
A SIGNIFICANT CONFESSION.
"OFFICERS ALL DRUNK.”
CORRESPONDENTS EXPERIENCES.

Mr. Reginald Wyon, the Correspondent of the Daily Mail at Vienna, arrived at Alexandrie on Saturday evening by the Russian steamer Emperor Nicholas II., from Crete, and is staying at the Khedivial Hotel. He was at Canea during the time the Russian Fleet was there and gives a terrible account of the outrages committed by the officers and men.

During the thirteen days he stayed at Canea the streets were quite unsafe. Any woman found in the streets was pursued and treated with great rudeness, if the miscreants happened to catch her. The bars were looted
and the restaurants were wrecked. Officers and men I were often "roaring" drunk at 9 a.m., and many
of them lay in a helpless state of intoxication all about the quay and streets. The Cretans

characterized them as absolute barbarians. | Both officers and men spent any amount of money at Canea and at night the scenes baffled description. All the sailors used to come ashore, while many lived on shore and overstayed their leave with impunity. When evening came on bands of them used to raid the streets and the fighting amongst themselves was of a ferocious description. In one night alone three Russians were killed by their fellows in a most brutal manner, for they were jumped upon as they lay prostrate until their skulls were completely smashed in!
A significant confession, Mr. Wyon informed | us, was made by many of the officers and men I while at Canea. They declared that they were all drink on the night of the incident on the

Dogger Bank. They all expressed a bitter hate | of England. Mr. Wyon was himself attacked | by drunken sailors while riding in the country in the presence of some officers, who did not take the slightest notice. His immunity from serious maltreatment during his stay at Canea was due to the fact that he pretended to be a | German, as no Englishman's life would have been secure at the hands of these ruffians. All the sailors expressed open contempt of the capacity of their officers.

The following incident is sufficient to show I the discipline prevailing. Two officers of I different ranks had a dispute on board a destroyer. They quarreled in front of the crew and the inferior officer drew a revolver on his superior. The latter jumped into the sea to save his life, but as he could not swim he was nearly drowned. He was picked up and got ashore, where he stayed for three days, during which time he was always drunk. On the fourth day he came aboard and made it up with the other officers. This destroyer is now lat Piraeus. She ran down & Greek vessel after leaving Crete, and damaged herself so considerably that she had to go into dock at Piraeus.
Mr. Wyon speaks some Slav and he interviewed a number of the men. He was struck by the great respect with which they spoke of the Japanese
A number of colliers are still at Souda Bay Awaiting the arrival of more Russian vessels.
THE BALTIC FLEET.
DEPARTURE FROM SUEZ.
SHIPS COAL IN BAY.
( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)

Suez, November 27. The Baltic Fleet sailed this morning escorted by the Coast Guard cruisers Abbas and Nourel-Bahr up to Sadwan in order to carry out Egypt's neutrality. Yesterday the warships and destroyers coaled from transports in the bay
The British yacht Emerald has just obtained a permit for her departure. Her destination is undeclared.
It is stated that the Canal dues for the fleet amounted to 370,000 fra.
Mr. Maximoff, the Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, returned to Cairo El from Port Said on Saturday morning.

TRANSPORTS AT PORT SAID. H. M. transport Assaye (Capt. E. K. Dowell, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Saturday afternoon, outward bound for Bombay. The troops on board, including women and children, numbered 1,489 of all ranks. Col. W. H. Murray, 1st Battalion Royal Scots, was the officer commanding.
The homeward bound transport Sicilia was due at Port Said early this morning.
GRAND HOTEL BONNARD,
ALEXANDRIA. 8a. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED.
WINDSOR HOTEL.
Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandra. Facing the road Central position. Under English management 173.11-901
CONDITION OF HELOUAN.
PETITION OF INHABITANTS.
The following is the text of a petition submitted by the inhabitants of Helouan Town to the Earl of Cromer, the Minister of Public Works, the Minister of Finance, and the Minister of the Interior:
"The undersigned, owners of property in, and residents of Helouan, beg to submit on behalf of themselves, other inhabitants and visitors to the town of Helouan the following:-!

1. They invite the attention of the Govern- ! ment to the many previous complaints they have made with regard to the unsatisfactory working of the Cairo-Helouan Railway Co., and they request the authorities to take the oppor. tunity of the transfer of the concession of the Helouan Railway Co. to the Delta Light Railway Company to safeguard the interests of Helouan and its inhabitants in promoting a thoroughly efficient service.

2. They draw the attention of the authorities to the present condition of the streets and roads both as regards cleanliness, lighting and repair, to the unfiltered and therefore dirty condition of the water supplied to the houses for drinking and other purposes, and they also feel very considerably the absence of any road for vehicular traffic between Cairo and Helouan. There are also several matters of less importance, such as the embellishment of the town, the providing of public attractions, and the planting of trees along the streets, which they think should be taken in hand.

3. Since the crying needs of the town are so great they think it a great hardship that money derived from the local taxation should be allocated to objects in which they have no concern-for instance, the amount paid by the town of Helouan last year in house-tax, water and other rates amounted to about £6,000, of which sum only about £1,750 was allotted to the town of Helouan.
4. They also object to the constitution of the present Local Commission :
Firstly, inasmuch as its members have no real power in promoting the interests of the town.

Secondly, the unworkable character of the Commission, the official members not being responsible to the Commission as a body but to the heads of the departments of which they happen to be the nominees. They therefore humbly request the conversion of the Local Commission into a genuine responsible "Municipality," or that the administration of the town be placed in charge of a Government Department, as it was before the creation of the Local Commission.

5. Owing to the urgency of these grievances your petitioners beg and pray that there petition be considered at an early date so that it | possibly the financial part may be rectified in this year's coming Budget.
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY. The next meeting of the Municipal Commission will take place on Wednesday, the 30th inst. at 9 p.m. The following is the official programme of the proceedings -
1. Communications diverses (lettre ministé. rielle relative au nouveau réglement sur les pharmaciens).
2. Rapport du Comité spécial, au sujet du collecteur-Est.
3. Administrateur délégué auprès de lal! Compagnie des Baux. 4. Demandes de crédits :
1) pour la construction de chambres au-dessus de la nouvelle aile de la Bibliothèque.
2) pour aménagements à faire au fort Kamarieh, en vue de la rage.
3) pour gratifications aux percepteurs.
4) pour la souscription à un dictionnaire français-arabe.
5) pour affaires judiciaires. Virement de crédit.
5. Question relative à la construction de maisons à bon marché.
6. Question relative à la Commission des travaux d'entretien des quais et à la durée de la période d'entretien des travaux.
7. Demande d'organisation d'un service de camions automobiles par Mr. Théodoridis.
8. Question relative à la tour dite des Romains.

ABBAS HELMY THEATRE. The final performance of the Italian opera company which has been performing at this theater for the past month was given last night, Il Trovatore being staged, while Mignon was given in the afternoon, before a large and delighted audience. It goes without saying that with such artists as Signa. Monti-Baldini and Sig. Tomasini, the representation of the opera was excellent. | Carmen was given on the previous evening, | when Signa. Monti-Baldini gave of her best. JA better Carmen than that presented by this

charming artiste it would be impossible to find. Signa Monti-Baldini throws her whole soul into the character and invests it with a degree of interest which we have found lacking in most other exponents.
The company leaves for Cairo to-day and will open at the Verdi Theatre, probably on Wednesday, with Aida.

ZIZINIA THEATRE. M. de Tisci Rubini, the celebrated bass, will take the role of King Mark in Tristan et Iseult at the Zizinis Theater this evening, on the occasion of the opening performance of the Italian opera company,
NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
SINKING OF BRITISH PINNACE.
(FROM OUR OW2 CORRESPONDENT).
Suakin, November 19. H. M. S. Sealark left here on the 7th inat. for
survey work and returned yesterday. Dur. ng surveying operations the
vessel encountered heavy weather, which caused the loss of her steam
pinnace. The latter was being loved by the Sealark while they were
making for some landmarks. A heavy ses swept over the pinnace and caused
it to sink. She then burned over and in doing so the tow ropes broke.
She sank in about 40 fathoms of water. No explosion of the boiler
occurred and ill hands were saved.
A football match takes place this afternoon between H.M.8. Sealark and
“Suakin." The local team stands a good chance of winning as they have
had a good deal of practice lately and have some excellent players,
including Kaimakam Drury Bey.
The Khedivial mail steamer arrived here from Suez on the 17th and brought
about 74 passengers for Suakin. Amongst them were Mr. and Mrs. Gaiger,
the former English secretary to the Director, Sudan Railways, Suakin,
and Mr. Maylor, the engineer sent out to erect the condensers for the
Suakin Railway. Mr. Bailey, head foreman of works, Suakin, had charge of
the temporary erection of the two condenser boilers, and Mr. Maylor will
erect the remainder.
Bimbashi P. C. Lord, R.E., Acting Chief Engineer, Buskin Railway, has
been confined to his house for the last fortnight through illness, but
is now feeling better, and it is hoped that in a few days he will be
able to resume his duties.
The telephone exchange is now complete between Suakin and Graham's Point,
and all the offices at both ends can now communicate with each other.
Telephone communication is also being pushed forward on the railway
line, under the supervision of Corporal George, R.E. They have reached
Handoub already and in a day or two will be at Railhead, so that Suakin,
Graham's Point, and Railhead will be in communication.
Colonel Macauley Bey, Director, Sudan Rail. ways, is expected here by the
next steamer from Suez.
It is rumored that H.E. Sirdar is likely to pay a visit here in
March.
The 8.8. Mahallah, which arrived here on the 17th inst., brought an
engineer and several workmen with implements and tools for the digging
of wells at Sheikh Barghout, which of course is to be the new Sudan
port.
Mr. Achille-Kredi, the sub-contractor of the new Alexandria quays,
arrived by the same steamer in order to study the place. He will
probably obtain contracts for dredging the barbour, constructing quays,
eto. He returned to Suez to-day by the S.S. Rahmanieh.
The 8.8. Calioubieh arrived here from Suez yesterday with stores for the
Suakin-Atbara Railway and machinery for well-sinking at Sheikh
Barghout
PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS Les passagers suivants sont arrivés Samedi, le 26 Ct. du Pirée, Smyrne, Métélin et Constantinople par le Paquebot "Tomailia," Commandant Gatteschi de la Khedivial Mail Lino:

M. et Mme W. B. Rees et famille. M. et Mme J. Wolters, M. Le Comte de Los, N. Dilaveri, A. Sahtouris, E. Sabati, S. Barker, Mme Gry. paris, Maitre C. Lytzicas, N. Joannidis, E.Weel, N. Velissarato, P. Caramadjianni, J. Caradja, P. Caradzas et son oncle, P. Anastassiou, G. Argyrogla, M. Vozikis, B. Georgiadis, N. Zoulias, C. Pezus, N.
